verses.text: Benjamin became the father of Bela his firstborn, Ashbel the second, Aharah the third,
verses.comment: Verse lists Benjamin’s sons. Names consistent with parallel genealogies, minor spelling differences between texts.

verses.text: Nohah the fourth, and Rapha the fifth.
verses.comment: Lists the remaining sons. Some transliterations differ in older translations.

verses.text: Bela’s sons were Addar, Gera, Abihud,
verses.comment: Genealogy continues. Addar likely same as Ard (Gen 46:21).

verses.text: Abishua, Naaman, Ahoah,
verses.comment: Names agree with other biblical lists, with some minor spelling change.

verses.text: Gera, Shephuphan, and Huram.
verses.comment: Completes the genealogy of Bela’s sons.

verses.text: These are the sons of Ehud, the heads of families living in Geba, who were exiled to Manahath:
verses.comment: Refers to descendants of Ehud, likely not the judge. Note the exile event.

verses.text: Naaman, Ahijah, and Gera. Gera led them into exile, fathering Uzza and Ahihud.
verses.comment: Clarifies lineage and the exile. Meaning is maintained.

verses.text: Shaharaim had children in the country of Moab after sending away his wives Hushim and Baara.
verses.comment: Indicates divorce/separation before his children in Moab.

verses.text: With his wife Hodesh, Shaharaim fathered Jobab, Zibia, Mesha, Malcam,
verses.comment: Continues the genealogy from a different wife.

verses.text: Jeuz, Sachia, and Mirmah. These were his sons, family heads.
verses.comment: Confirms these sons as tribal leaders.

verses.text: He also had sons by Hushim: Abitub and Elpaal.
verses.comment: Adds sons from another wife, following Hebrew ordering.

verses.text: Elpaal’s sons: Eber, Misham, and Shemed. Shemed built Ono and Lod, with its settlements.
verses.comment: Provides historical note about towns built.

verses.text: Beriah and Shema were family heads living in Aijalon. They drove out the inhabitants of Gath.
verses.comment: Describes military action by these leaders.

verses.text: Ahio, Shashak, Jeremoth,
verses.comment: Continues genealogy; names only.

verses.text: Zebadiah, Arad, Eder,
verses.comment: Names consistent with original text.

verses.text: Michael, Ishpah, and Joha, sons of Beriah.
verses.comment: Text is a direct rendering.

verses.text: Zebadiah, Meshullam, Hizki, Heber,
verses.comment: List continues with tribal genealogy.

verses.text: Ishmerai, Izliah, and Jobab, sons of Elpaal.
verses.comment: Names maintained faithfully.

verses.text: Jakim, Zichri, Zabdi,
verses.comment: Direct translation of the genealogy.

verses.text: Elienai, Zillethai, Eliel,
verses.comment: Maintains order and spelling from manuscripts.

verses.text: Adaiah, Beraiah, and Shimrath, sons of Shimei.
verses.comment: Direct list of sons.

verses.text: Ishpan, Eber, Eliel,
verses.comment: Continues genealogy.

verses.text: Abdon, Zichri, Hanan,
verses.comment: Names as found in the Hebrew text.

verses.text: Hananiah, Elam, Anthothijah,
verses.comment: Literal names translated.

verses.text: Iphdeiah, and Penuel, sons of Shashak.
verses.comment: Genealogy list continues.

verses.text: Shamsherai, Shehariah, Athaliah,
verses.comment: Direct translation of names.

verses.text: Jaareshiah, Elijah, and Zichri, sons of Jeroham.
verses.comment: List formatted for clarity.

verses.text: These were heads of their families by their generations. They lived in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Notes position and location.

verses.text: Jeiel, the father of Gibeon, lived in Gibeon. His wife’s name was Maacah.
verses.comment: Regroups verse for clarity. ‘father’ means founder or prominent ancestor.

verses.text: His firstborn was Abdon, then Zur, Kish, Baal, Nadab,
verses.comment: List of sons. Common names 'Kish' and 'Baal' noted.

verses.text: Gedor, Ahio, and Zecher.
verses.comment: Additional sons listed.

verses.text: Mikloth fathered Shimeah. They lived near their relatives in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: ‘Near their relatives’ follows Hebrew ‘against’ or ‘beside’.

verses.text: Ner fathered Kish. Kish fathered Saul. Saul fathered Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal.
verses.comment: Eshbaal same as Ishbosheth, alternate name (see 2 Sam. 2:8).

verses.text: The son of Jonathan was Meribbaal, and Meribbaal fathered Micah.
verses.comment: Meribbaal is also Mephibosheth in 2 Samuel.

verses.text: Micah’s sons: Pithon, Melech, Tarea, and Ahaz.
verses.comment: Direct genealogical list.

verses.text: Ahaz fathered Jehoaddah. Jehoaddah fathered Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri. Zimri fathered Moza.
verses.comment: Names may vary slightly across translations.

verses.text: Moza fathered Binea. Raphah was his son, Eleasah his son, Azel his son.
verses.comment: Maintains lineage order from Hebrew.

verses.text: Azel had six sons—Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. All were Azel’s sons.
verses.comment: Genealogy carefully retained. Hebrew term ‘sons’ is literal.

verses.text: The sons of Eshek, Azel’s brother: Ulam his firstborn, Jeush the second, Eliphelet the third.
verses.comment: Direct translation; possible minor variant in some texts.

verses.text: The sons of Ulam were mighty warriors, archers. They had many sons and grandsons—150 in all. All these were among the descendants of Benjamin.
verses.comment: Concludes genealogy; ‘mighty warriors’/‘men of strength’ is a literal translation.
